<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_get_timestamp:
```c
unsigned long long metal_get_timestamp(void)
{
	unsigned long long t = 0;
	struct timespec tp;
	int r;

	r = clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &tp);
	if (r == -1) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
		return t;
	}
	t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S);
	t += tp.tv_nsec;

	return t;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: No other fragments in the provided code appear to rely on compiler language extensions. The function metal_get_timestamp uses standard C constructs and POSIX APIs (struct timespec, clock_gettime, CLOCK_MONOTONIC) which are OS APIs rather than compiler language extensions. The NS_PER_S macro is a plain integer macro definition and simple arithmetic in the function (tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S), tp.tv_nsec) uses standard C operators and types. The call site metal_log(...) in the function is a normal macro invocation; the potentially non-standard constructs are contained in the macro definition above, which should be investigated (it embeds a statement-expression '({ ... })' and the token pasting '##__VA_ARGS__', both known to be compiler-specific extensions). No other constructs (e.g., nested functions, typeof, labels-as-values, inline assembly, or other common compiler extensions) are present in the supplied code.
